title: 9  Confidence and Humility
text:
9.2 Teaching/Facilitating with Intellectual Humility
Intellectual humility is the awareness that one’s knowledge is limited and the willingness to revise perspectives considering new evidence or experiences. For educators of adult learners, intellectual humility is not simply a personal trait—it is a leadership stance that shapes how learning communities function. When teachers acknowledge their own limits and invite learners’ insights, they model openness and foster more authentic engagement.
The Foundation for Critical Thinking (2014) defines intellectual humility in this way:

Having a consciousness of the limits of one’s knowledge, including a sensitivity to circumstances in which one’s native egocentrism is likely to function self-deceptively; sensitivity to bias, prejudice, and limitations of one’s viewpoint. Intellectual humility depends on recognizing that one should not claim more than one actually knows. It does not imply spinelessness or submissiveness. It implies the lack of intellectual pretentiousness, boastfulness, or conceit, combined with insight into the logical foundations, or lack of such foundations, of one’s beliefs. (Foundation for Critical Thinking, 2014)


What is Intellectual Humility?
As humans, we tend to believe that we are correct about what we know and believe.
What It Is: Psychologists describe intellectual humility as recognizing the boundaries of your own knowledge and being open to learning from others (Porter & Schumann, 2018). Intellectual humility also means we are open to learning more, to changing our beliefs as we learn more.
Intellectual humility is different from self-doubt; rather, it combines confidence with curiosity. “People who lack self-confidence might doubt their beliefs not because they are intellectually humble but rather because they evaluate their knowledge or intellectual ability unfavorably” (Leary et al., 2017, p. 794). Instead, those who are intellectually humble demonstrate confidence in their intellectual abilities—but also understand that they do not know everything, and they may need more information, experience, or expertise to learn further.

Intellectual humility is defined as recognizing that a particular personal belief may be fallible, accompanied by an appropriate attentiveness to limitations in the evidentiary basis of that belief and to one’s own limitations in obtaining and evaluating relevant information (Leary et al., 2017, p. 793).

In other words, intellectual humility is not simply being open to learning, but also seeking out that learning so we can become more certain of our beliefs and knowledge.
What it means for us: As teachers and learners, we can enter learning spaces and experiences with “a willingness to recognize the limits of one’s knowledge and appreciate others’ intellectual strengths” (Porter & Schumann, 2018, p. 140).
Intellectual humility allows us to enter our teaching and learning experience with the understanding that we have something to give and something to learn. With intellectual humility, we acknowledge that we always have something more to learn.

Some people are generally inclined to view their opinions, beliefs, and positions as subject to further consideration – that is intellectually humble. Yet, even those individuals are likely to have certain views that they are unwilling, or at least unlikely, to reconsider even when confronted with evidence that they could be wrong (Hoyle et al., 2016, p. 165).

As Hoyle et al. (2016) note here, most of have some areas of our lives in which we are likely to be unmoved, even when presented with evidence that suggests our ideas or knowledge is not valid.
Why It Matters for Adult Learners: Adults arrive in classrooms with diverse professional, cultural, and personal experiences. When educators practice intellectual humility, they validate learners as co-contributors to knowledge. Intellectual humility promotes empathy, reduces polarization, and strengthens dialogue across differences. These qualities directly support the creation of inclusive and authentic learning communities.
Humans have a natural inclination to want to be considered knowledgeable. And, as teachers, facilitators, and leaders, that natural inclination can be even stronger. We might believe we should have the answers to questions that are asked, so that we should know more about a topic than we actually know.

People with high intellectual humility might feel less motivated to defend their correctness and intellectual superiority because they are more comfortable acknowledging their intellectual fallibility. We therefore predict that intellectual humility will be associated with openness to learning about opposing perspectives, even during disagreements about highly charged topics (Porter & Schumann, 2018, p. 140).

Funds of Knowledge: As discussed previously, adult learners bring a vast variety of life experience, professional expertise, cultural understanding, social support, and prior educational knowledge into their learning experiences. They also bring with them what Moll et al. (1992) defines as funds of knowledge. “We use the term ‘funds of knowledge’ to refer to these historically accumulate and culturally developed bodies of knowledge and skills essential for household or individual functioning and well-being” (Moll et al., 1992, p. 133).
Intellectual Humility in Practice: As adult educators, we have the opportunity to facilitate learning from a place of intellectual humility, acknowledging the funds of knowledge our students bring with them into their learning. When we incorporate a servant leadership perspective with intellectual humility, we will seek to engage people’s heads, hearts and hopes and empower learners to turn their newfound knowledge and skills into action.
We encourage you to consider how you can infuse your role as teacher, facilitator, or leaders with a focus on the common good, seeking ways to engage confidently in contemporary cultural tensions. With students who are Christian, this perspective of the common good finds its roots and expression in a relationship with Jesus Christ. For students who are not of the Christian faith, strive to espouse this in word and example in a way that is respectful of their heritage and traditions while at the same time giving them an understanding of the Christian worldview. Take the time to listen to those you teach, learning from them what is important to them and seeking to understand their beliefs to build bridges of understanding through respect.
Dr. Adrienne Castellon, a former faculty member at Trinity Western University, shares these thoughts on how her core values influence her teaching:

Realizing that our core values, personality traits, and characteristics impact how we learn and teach, take the time to discern your essential values. For example, I have identified the following six essential values to incorporate into my life and teaching: honesty, integrity, persistence, desire to learn, compassion/empathy and community. Because I value compassion/empathy and community, I put the learner first and design my curricula and methodologies to suit the learners in my class. Because I value persistence and the desire to learn, I don’t give up on students and I try to find ways to help them learn through different methods and alternate ways that they can demonstrate their learning.

These values direct my entire teaching methodology; I espouse the goals of differentiated instruction (basically changing instructional methods to adapt to different learners) and aim to create a space for learning that empowers all students to succeed. For more information, see “Differentiated Instruction | Definition, Strategies & Examples” (Study.com, n.d.) as a supplementary resource.
Differentiated Instruction: One way to demonstrate intellectual humility, is to acknowledge that we all learn differently. Differentiated instruction can become a seamless part of your instructional planning and practice. Differentiated instruction is a teaching approach in which you tailor your teaching and learning activities to meet the diverse needs of learners in your classroom or training session.
You can practice differentiated instruction by intentionally creating opportunities to learn about students’ strengths, needs, interests, preferences, and ways of learning. The online tool “What’s Your Learning Style?” is an example of a self-assessment tool to help identify a learner’s learning style. To this end you can use meaningful strategies and ongoing assessment and adjustment. You can differentiate the content, process, or product components of the learning experience by using a range of strategies and methods, e.g., anchor activities, tiered lessons, small-group instruction, and varied tasks. Visit Differentiated Instruction (LINCS, n.d.) to learn more.
Please take the time to explore the resources linked in the notes and other resources in your Brookfield and Preskill (2016) and Silberman and Biech (2015) texts. The approach taken throughout this course is an intellectually humble one. In chapters five and six, Brookfield and Preskill (2016) particularly address the power dynamic in the classroom, awareness of which may foster a more intellectually humble approach. You are encouraged to use your texts as primary resources for more detailed information about specific strategies and approaches to contributing as an adult educator while remaining intellectually humble.


9.2.1 Activity: Cognitive and Interpersonal Features of Intellectual Humility






Estimated Time: 60 minutes

As you read this article, self-evaluate your level of openness, curiosity, tolerance of ambiguity and dogmatism.
In your reflective journal, consider:

What two or three actions can you incorporate into your practice as an adult educator and leader to nurture your own intellectual humility and foster it in your students?





9.2.2 Activity: Openness to Learning






Estimated Time: 45 minutes



Watch Farah Nasser presenting on “The Power of Intellectual Humility” (TEDx Talks, 2019).

As you reflect on this talk, consider the following:

9.2.3 Activity: Reflection and Discussion






Estimated Time: 75 minutes



As we finish this unit, let’s pause and turn inward. Self-awareness and intellectual humility are not only ideas to think about—they are also practices we can feel and live in our bodies.
Personal reflection (choose one practice): Take 10–15 minutes to engage in a quiet activity that helps you center yourself.
You might:

Take a short walk outdoors, noticing what comes into awareness with each step.
Brew a cup of tea or coffee, paying attention to the ritual of preparing and savoring it.
Sit quietly and take three deep breaths, noticing the rhythm of your body.

title: 9  Confidence and Humility
text:
Summary
In this unit, we have explored the inward dimensions of becoming authentic and effective adult educators. Teaching begins with self-awareness. By learning to know ourselves—our values, strengths, and limitations—we create the foundation to trust our own presence in the classroom. As Palmer (2017) explains, “we teach who we are” (p. 2), reminding us that authenticity and inner clarity are essential to building trust with learners. This self-trust enables us to engage learners with confidence and openness, even in moments of uncertainty.
Alongside self-knowledge, we also considered the practice of intellectual humility. For adult educators, intellectual humility is not about diminishing our own expertise, but about modeling curiosity, openness to new perspectives, and a willingness to learn from students as well as colleagues. This practice allows us to foster authentic relationships, strengthen trust in the learning community, and invite shared exploration rooted in respect and mutual growth.

Your platform of beliefs is a foundation for how you approach teaching and facilitation as an adult educator. It brings together your values, your understanding of adult learning theories, and your commitment to creating authentic learning communities.

10.2 Creating Learning Outcomes
Before determining what we will teach, we need to consider what students will learn. As teachers and facilitators, we may be asked to teach a course that already has learning outcomes – or conduct a training for an employer that knows exactly what they want their employees to know at the end of the training. In that case, we can review those learning outcomes, and then design learning experiences that ensure students learn what we want them to learn. However, sometimes we are the ones tasked with developing the learning outcomes—that is, we are responsible for determining what want participants in our course or training to learn. Thus, will review here how to write an effective learning outcome.
Learning outcomes, simply put, encapsulate in a short sentence, what we want students/employees to learn. To consider this, we can begin by asking ourselves this question:

What essential learning must take place for students to learn the knowledge/skills/values to prepare for higher-level coursework or engage in the profession?

Learning outcomes allow us to ensure that both students and instructors know why they are engaging in the learning process. Our goal, after all, as teachers and facilitators, is not just to teach or facilitate – but for students/employees to learn. As Barr and Tagg (1995) put it, “Our mission is not instruction but rather producing learning with eery student by whatever means works best” (p. 13). When we create learning outcomes, we are thinking then, of what we want students/employees to learn. Only with a strong learning outcome can we move forward to design the learning experience so students/employees are able to achieve that learning outcome.

10.4 Administrative and Supervisory Aspects of an Adult Educator
Teaching a group of learners also involves non-instructional duties. Sometimes there is a tension between our philosophical beliefs about authentic teaching and learning and the organizational realities we face. In addition to creating authentic learning experiences, your teaching responsibilities will often require you to track and report on learners’ progress, submit grades or summary reports to the organization, order textbooks or supplies, work with an assistant such as a learning coach or teacher assistant, book classrooms…The possibilities are many!
Beyond your own classroom, you may be asked to contribute to committees and other meetings about the operational aspects of the education facility. Few educators work alone. We are almost all part of an organizational context which has implications for our work. Organizations have expectations and the relationship between the adult educator and the organization is important to consider. Sometimes what is asked of us organizationally will conflict with our philosophy of how to carry out assessment or what it means to advise and guide students on their educational journey. The time invested in meetings is important for the organization to flourish and enable the teaching and learning to happen at all yet, this time commitment can detract from planning authentic learning experiences and having the time to give extensive formative feedback. Every organization is driven by a set of values which will apply to the educational environment. If there is an outside funder for example, then reports to demonstrate progress and results will need great care and handling since this is what makes programs possible at all. Educators must not only promote what they consider the best way to do things but also consider what others expect and need from the program.
During this course you have focused on how to develop authentic learning communities. Authentic learning communities take place within organizational contexts. Priorities between these two—developing authentic learning communities and organizational realities—are not always aligned. However, it behooves the critical thinker to figure out how to align them as much as possible. This is a challenge worth embracing to be personally and professionally fulfilled.

No matter how hopeful our dialogue has been, no matter how many of our colleagues have embraced a new vision, no matter how many practical possibilities we have explored, someone will say, ‘These are wonderful ideas, but every last one of them will be defeated by conditions in my school’ (Palmer, 2017, p. 170).

Palmer (2017) suggests that change begins when we, as individual teachers and facilitators, “make an inward decision to live ‘divided no more,’ finding a center for their lives outside of institutions” and “begin to discover one another and form communities of congruence that offer mutual support and opportunities to develop a shared vision” (pp. 172-173).

Create a visual representation of the process you went through to develop your platform of beliefs and design the learning experience. Through this artifact, we want to be able to see your thought process, including how you determined the beliefs that matter most to you about adult teaching and learning.
The learning artifact should illustrate:

How you identified what to include in your platform of beliefs, including the resources used.
The process you engaged in to design the adult learning experience, including the resources used.
The artifact can be submitted in any format you choose. Examples include a concept map, annotated diagram, infographic, or storyboard. You could make a video diary of the process, take photos of yourself at your desk thinking about your beliefs, or include a link to a LinkedIn post you wrote about the process. You can be creative here, but the goal is to make your

your thinking visible. Be sure to clearly show how you developed your platform of beliefs and how those beliefs and the theories and strategies you learned about in this course shaped your design of the learning experience. (Note: You can use AI tools to assist with visuals, but annotations and reflections must be authored by you.)
4. Critical Reflection (2–3 pages)

Analyze how the learning experience you designed demonstrates achievement of the learning outcomes for this course. (Refer to the Course Overview to refresh yourself on the course learning outcomes).
Reflect on how your platform of beliefs will influence your future teaching and facilitation of adult learners.
Identify areas in which you hope to continue to grow and learn as a teacher/facilitator, so you can create and facilitate authentic learning communities.

Guidelines for the use of AI in this assignment

You may use AI tools for brainstorming, drafting, or creating visuals.
All AI-assisted work must be clearly annotated or acknowledged.

Discussions

Unit 1 Discussion

Activity: Reflective Discussion






Estimated Time: 75 minutes



After completing this unit, including the learning activities, you will write in your Reflective Journal. This activity will prepare you for future activities in this course, including your final assignment. Use the following to guide your reflection and writing:
Part 1: Incorporating the readings in Unit 1, write a 150-250-word discussion post that addresses the following:

List and describe three values you hold related to teaching and learning.
Write a personal statement about your identity as a teacher, coach, or facilitator.

Part 2: For the second part of your discussion, write a 150-250 response to the following:

Consider the key elements of authentic learning spaces, outlined by Palmer (2017) in Chapter 3. Select two of these elements that you consider to be important.
Introduce the element and discuss some practical steps you could take to create an authentic learning space.

Be sure to cite Palmer (2017) and other authors in your journal to demonstrate ways in which your thinking aligns with, contrasts with, or builds on the writing of the authors.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 2 Discussion

Activity: Who Are You?






Estimated Time: 45 minutes



For this activity, you are asked to share a little more about yourself with your learning community. First, find a quote about either identity or integrity. For example, you may want to perform a Google image search for “identity quote.” Find one that resonates with you and then include a picture of something that tells us something about you. Post the quote and your image to the learning community or your preferred social network service with a 1-2 sentence explanation.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 3 Discussion

Activity: Belonging Learning Activity






Estimated Time: 60 minutes



Based on the learning activities in this unit, create a learning activity you would use in a course that incorporates elements of belonging, discussed in the course readings and your blog posts. Include the learning outcome for the activity, the learning activity, and a discussion of how the different elements of the learning activity would serve to support a sense of belonging for students.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 4 Discussion

Activity: Reflection & Discussion






Estimated Time: 60 minutes



After completing this unit, including the learning activities, you will write a 250-word reflective notes on the following:

Provide a brief description of each of the three models (with citations as appropriate).
Select the learning community model that most closely aligns with your identity and values as a teacher/facilitator. Describe the strengths you see in this model, explaining why it resonates with your concepts of teaching and learning.

Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 5 Discussion

Activity: Appreciative Interview






Estimated Time: 120 minutes



In this discussion, you will interview a friend or colleague. Select someone who is also a coach, teacher or facilitator—or select another student. You may also choose to complete this interview with a group. By conducting an appreciative interview, you will explore strategies for creating inclusive, collaborative learning communities.
Part 1
Read the article, “Appreciative Interviews (AI)” (Liberating Structures, n.d.). As you read, you will see that these instructions are developed for groups. However, if you are conducting your interview with an individual, you may still find these instructions helpful.
Next, read “119+ Appreciative Inquiry Interview Questions and Examples” (Moore, 2019).
First, develop a minimum of five questions to guide the interview process. The questions should be developed based on your course learning to date, and should integrate the articles, TED talks, short films, and other resources we have reviewed together. Building on your learning, develop at least five questions that you will ask another learner, to answer the guiding questions of this unit:

What strategies invite students to engage in collaborative learning?
What strategies can you use in online learning environments to support connections between students?

Part 2
Then, contact your friend or colleague and schedule a time to meet, preferably face-to-face, or through zoom, skype, some other form of video conferencing, or by phone.
Part 3
After you have completed the interview, prepare a 250-word reflection on what you have learned from the interview, identifying at least three strategies you can use to engage students in collaborative learning as well as strategies you can use to support connections between students in online learning environments. Be sure to reference the other learner for her/his original ideas.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 7 Discussion

Activity: Servant Leadership Video






Estimated Time: 30 minutes



Watch “Servant Leadership: How a jar can change the way you lead and serve” (TEDx Talks, 2017). As you watch the video, consider: How might assumption and perceptions impact your role as an adult educator? How are adult educators servant leaders?
Questions to Consider

How are you going to live out the seven concepts of intentional practice Frett outlines? List each of the concepts and how you could live each one.
Reference the Silberman and Brookfield texts and find one strategy to apply to each of the seven concepts. List each concept of intentional practice and your chosen strategy beside it, include a brief description of the strategy.
In a general manner, explain how to use the strategies with intentionality to be a servant leader in the adult learning environment.

Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 8 Discussion

Activity: Interconnectedness and Relationship Networks






Estimated Time: 150 minutes



Read Chapter 6, “Interconnectedness,” in Who Do We Choose to Be: Facing Reality, Claiming Leadership, Restoring Sanity (Wheatley, 2017).
As you read this chapter, think about Archbishop Desmond Tutu’s comment: “We exist in a bundle of life. We say, ‘A person is a person through other people.’ It is not ‘I think therefore I am’ [but rather] I am human because I belong. I participate, I share” (as cited in Wheatley, 2017, p. 223).
Based on the reading, reflect on the following questions:

Who has influenced you to become the person you are? Who do you depend on as ground and support for your life?
Demonstrate your network of relationships and annotate with the key values or wisdom you have learned from each person.
Because of the influence of these individuals on your values, choose two strategies from Brookfield or Silberman and show how they align with these values. (Choose strategies not previously described in your response.)

Create a concept map to show your networks of relationships using tools such as bubbl.us or popplet.com, or on paper, take a picture and include it in your post. Reflect on how this relates to your teaching/facilitating work.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.





Unit 9 Discussion

Activity: Reflection and Discussion






Estimated Time: 75 minutes



As we finish this unit, let’s pause and turn inward. Self-awareness and intellectual humility are not only ideas to think about — they are also practices we can feel and live in our bodies.
Personal Reflection (choose one): Take 10–15 minutes to engage in a quiet activity that helps you center yourself. You might:

Take a short walk outdoors, noticing what comes into awareness with each step.
Brew a cup of tea or coffee, paying attention to the ritual of preparing and savoring it.
Sit quietly and take three deep breaths, noticing the rhythm of your body.
Sketch or doodle freely for a few minutes, letting your hand move without judgment.

As you engage in this reflective experience, hold in mind these questions:

Who am I becoming as an educator?
How can I hold both confidence and humility in this role?

Share your insight: After your reflection, share the following in the learning community:

one insight you discovered about yourself through the practice
how that insight might influence the contribution you want to make as an adult educator
a way you plan to nurture intellectual humility in your teaching or learning environment

Engage with others: Read the reflections of your peers. Notice what resonates with you or expands your perspective. Respond to at least two (2) peers, practicing humility by naming what you learned from their insights or how their experience challenged or enriched your own.
Note: This activity serves as the discussion prompt for this unit. Share your response and connect with others in the Learning Community to deepen your understanding.
